Food Safety Guide for Pregnancy.disclaimer: This guide is for informational purposes. Always consult your healthcare provider or a registered dietitian for personalized medical advice.

apple.advice: Wash thoroughly before eating. Excellent source of fiber and vitamins.

nutrition.details: High in fiber (aids digestion), Vitamin C (boosts immunity), and various antioxidants.

banana.advice: Rich in potassium; good for digestion and preventing muscle cramps.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of potassium, Vitamin B6, and provides quick energy from natural sugars.

orange.advice: Excellent source of Vitamin C and hydration. Wash skin before peeling.

nutrition.details: Packed with Vitamin C (for immunity and iron absorption) and folate.

mango.advice: Excellent source of vitamins. Enjoy ripe mangoes in moderation due to high sugar content.

nutrition.details: Rich in Vitamins A and C, which are important for immune function and fetal development.

mango.consumption: 1/2 to 1 mango per day in moderation

pineapple.advice: Safe in moderation. The enzyme bromelain is not harmful in normal food amounts. Can cause heartburn for some.

nutrition.details: High in Vitamin C and manganese. Contains bromelain, which aids digestion.

pomegranate.advice: Excellent source of iron and folate. Very beneficial during pregnancy.

nutrition.details: Rich in iron, folate, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, and powerful antioxidants.

grapes.advice: Safe when washed properly. Rich in antioxidants. Eat in moderation due to high sugar.

nutrition.details: Contain Vitamins C and K, antioxidants (like resveratrol), and provide hydration.

watermelon.advice: Hydrating and refreshing. Helps with morning sickness and hydration. Ensure it's fresh.

nutrition.details: High water content (90%+), provides Vitamins A and C, and lycopene.

avocado.advice: Rich in healthy fats and nutrients. Excellent for baby's brain development.

nutrition.details: Packed with healthy monounsaturated fats, folate, potassium, fiber, and Vitamin K.

strawberry.advice: Wash very thoroughly, as they can hold onto pesticides. Excellent Vitamin C source.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of Vitamin C, manganese, folate, and antioxidants.

blueberry.advice: A 'superfood' rich in antioxidants. Wash before eating.

nutrition.details: Packed with antioxidants, Vitamin C, Vitamin K, and fiber.

raspberry.advice: High in fiber, which helps with pregnancy-related constipation. Wash gently.

nutrition.details: Very high in fiber, Vitamin C, manganese, and antioxidants.

kiwi.advice: High in Vitamin C. Can help with sleep and digestion.

nutrition.details: Extremely high in Vitamin C, also provides Vitamin K, Vitamin E, and fiber.

pear.advice: Good source of fiber. Wash skin thoroughly before eating.

nutrition.details: Good source of fiber, Vitamin C, and potassium.

cherries.advice: Safe in moderation. Can help with inflammation. Wash well.

nutrition.details: Contain Vitamin C, antioxidants, and melatonin (which may aid sleep).

guava.advice: A tropical fruit powerhouse. Excellent for immunity. Wash well.

nutrition.details: Exceptionally high in Vitamin C, also provides fiber, Vitamin A, and folate.

jackfruit.advice: Ripe jackfruit is safe in moderation. Unripe jackfruit is safe when cooked as a vegetable.

nutrition.details: Good source of fiber, Vitamin C, potassium, and B vitamins.

custard apple.advice: Safe and nutritious. High in natural sugars, so eat in moderation.

nutrition.details: Rich in Vitamin C, Vitamin B6, fiber, and magnesium.

spinach.advice: High in iron and folate. Wash leaves thoroughly. Best eaten cooked to increase nutrient absorption.

nutrition.details: Packed with iron, folate (crucial for pregnancy), vitamins A, C, and K, and fiber.

broccoli.advice: Packed with vitamins and fiber. Cook lightly to preserve nutrients.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of Vitamin C, folate, fiber, iron, calcium, and Vitamin K.

carrots.advice: Excellent for vitamin A in safe amounts (beta-carotene). Wash and/or peel before eating.

nutrition.details: Rich in beta-carotene (converts to Vitamin A), fiber, and Vitamin K.

sweet potatoes.advice: Rich in vitamin A. Excellent complex carbohydrate source for sustained energy.

nutrition.details: Very high in beta-carotene, fiber, Vitamin C, and potassium.

tomatoes.advice: Rich in lycopene. Cooked tomatoes (in sauce) provide more available nutrients.

nutrition.details: Good source of Vitamin C, potassium, and the antioxidant lycopene.

bell peppers.advice: Excellent source of Vitamin C, especially red ones. Wash thoroughly.

nutrition.details: Very high in Vitamin C (red peppers are highest), also contain Vitamin A and antioxidants.

leafy greens.advice: Includes kale, collards, etc. Must be washed EXTREMELY well to avoid contamination. Best eaten cooked.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of folate, iron, calcium, fiber, and vitamins A, C, and K.

lettuce.advice: Romaine and dark-leaf lettuce are best. Wash meticulously, as it's a common source of foodborne illness.

nutrition.details: Provides folate and Vitamin K. Good for hydration.

cauliflower.advice: Versatile vegetable, good source of fiber and vitamins.

nutrition.details: Good source of Vitamin C, Vitamin K, folate, and fiber.

cucumber.advice: Hydrating. Wash skin thoroughly if eating unpeeled.

nutrition.details: High water content, provides some Vitamin K.

zucchini.advice: Safe and hydrating. Cook to improve digestion.

nutrition.details: Provides Vitamin C, potassium, and has high water content.

green beans.advice: Good source of vitamins. Must be eaten cooked.

nutrition.details: Good source of Vitamin C, Vitamin K, folate, and fiber.

peas.advice: Good source of plant-based protein and fiber.

nutrition.details: Contains fiber, protein, Vitamin A, Vitamin C, and Vitamin K.

corn.advice: Good source of energy. Best in moderation as it's starchy.

nutrition.details: Provides fiber, B vitamins, and carbohydrates for energy.

mushrooms.advice: Must be cooked thoroughly. Avoid raw mushrooms and wild/foraged mushrooms.

nutrition.details: Good source of B vitamins (like riboflavin) and selenium. Some (like cremini) provide Vitamin D.

onion.advice: Safe when cooked. Adds flavor and antioxidants.

nutrition.details: Provides flavor, antioxidants (quercetin), and some Vitamin C.

garlic.advice: Safe in culinary amounts. May cause heartburn in some.

nutrition.details: Contains allicin, which has immune-boosting properties.

ginger.advice: Excellent for nausea and morning sickness. Safe in culinary amounts.

nutrition.details: Valued for its anti-nausea and anti-inflammatory properties.

beets.advice: Good for blood pressure and folate. Best eaten cooked.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of folate, fiber, iron, and nitrates (which help blood pressure).

pumpkin.advice: Nutrient-dense vegetable, high in Vitamin A.

nutrition.details: Very high in beta-carotene (Vitamin A), fiber, and potassium.

okra.advice: Also known as Lady's Finger. Good source of fiber and folate.

nutrition.details: Good source of fiber (helps digestion), folate, and Vitamin C.

eggplant.advice: Also known as Brinjal. Must be cooked.

nutrition.details: Provides fiber and antioxidants.

cabbage.advice: Safe when cooked. Can cause gas, so eat in moderation.

nutrition.details: Good source of Vitamin C, Vitamin K, and fiber.

chicken_breast.advice: Cook thoroughly to 165°F (74°C). No pink inside. Excellent lean protein source.

nutrition.details: High-quality lean protein, iron, zinc, and B vitamins (especially B6 and Niacin).

turkey_breast.advice: Cook thoroughly to 165°F (74°C). A very lean protein alternative to chicken.

nutrition.details: Excellent lean protein, iron, zinc, phosphorus, and B vitamins.

beef_lean.advice: Must be cooked well-done (160°F or 71°C) with no pink. Excellent source of iron.

nutrition.details: Rich in high-quality protein, heme iron (easily absorbed), zinc, and Vitamin B12.

pork_lean.advice: Must be cooked well-done (160°F or 71°C). Choose lean cuts like tenderloin.

nutrition.details: Good source of protein, thiamine (Vitamin B1), and other B vitamins.

lamb.advice: Must be cooked well-done (160°F or 71°C). Good source of iron.

nutrition.details: Rich in protein, iron, zinc, and Vitamin B12.

salmon.advice: Cook thoroughly (145°F or 63°C). Excellent source of Omega-3s for baby's brain.

nutrition.details: Rich in Omega-3s (DHA/EPA), high-quality protein, Vitamin D, and B vitamins.

cod.advice: Cook thoroughly. A great low-mercury, low-fat fish.

nutrition.details: Excellent lean protein, Vitamin B12, and iodine.

tilapia.advice: Cook thoroughly. A common, safe, low-mercury fish.

nutrition.details: Good source of lean protein and Vitamin B12.

shrimp.advice: Must be cooked thoroughly (until pink and opaque). Low in mercury.

nutrition.details: Good source of lean protein, selenium, and iodine.

canned_light_tuna.advice: Limit due to mercury. 'Light' tuna (skipjack) is better than 'White' (albacore).

nutrition.details: Good source of protein and Omega-3s, but mercury is a concern.

canned_light_tuna.consumption: Limit to 1-2 servings per week (max 12oz total)

eggs.advice: Cook thoroughly until both yolk and white are firm. Avoid raw or runny eggs. Excellent source of choline.

nutrition.details: Complete protein, choline (crucial for brain development), iron, and vitamins A, D, B12.

lentils.advice: Great source of plant-based protein, iron, and fiber. Cook well for easy digestion.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of plant-based protein, folate, iron, and fiber (helps constipation).

chickpeas.advice: Versatile legume. Good source of protein, fiber, and folate.

nutrition.details: Good source of protein, fiber, folate, and iron.

kidney_beans.advice: Must be cooked thoroughly. Never eat raw or undercooked. Great for iron.

nutrition.details: High in protein, fiber, iron, and folate.

black_beans.advice: Cook thoroughly. Good source of fiber and protein.

nutrition.details: High in protein, fiber, folate, magnesium, and antioxidants.

tofu.advice: Good plant-based protein. Ensure it's freshly prepared and cooked.

nutrition.details: Complete plant protein, calcium (if set with calcium), iron, and isoflavones.

edamame.advice: Cooked soybeans. Great snack high in protein and folate.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of plant protein, folate, iron, and fiber.

paneer.advice: Safe if made from pasteurized milk. Good protein and calcium source for vegetarians.

nutrition.details: High-quality protein, calcium, and phosphorus. Can be high in fat.

milk.advice: Must be pasteurized. Excellent calcium source.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of calcium, Vitamin D (if fortified), protein, and B vitamins.

yogurt.advice: Must be pasteurized. Good source of calcium and probiotics (for gut health).

nutrition.details: Excellent source of calcium, protein, probiotics, and B vitamins.

greek_yogurt.advice: Pasteurized. Higher in protein than regular yogurt. Choose plain to avoid excess sugar.

nutrition.details: Very high in protein, calcium, and probiotics.

cottage_cheese.advice: Must be pasteurized. Great source of protein.

nutrition.details: High in protein, calcium, and phosphorus.

hard_cheese.advice: Includes cheddar, parmesan, mozzarella. Must be pasteurized. Good calcium source.

nutrition.details: Concentrated source of calcium, protein, and phosphorus. High in sodium and fat.

cream_cheese.advice: Must be pasteurized. High in fat, so use in moderation.

nutrition.details: Primarily fat, low in protein and calcium compared to other dairy.

ghee.advice: Clarified butter. Safe to use in cooking in moderation.

nutrition.details: Pure fat. Contains fat-soluble vitamins (A, E, K). Use sparingly.

oats.advice: Great source of fiber and energy. Helps prevent constipation.

nutrition.details: High in soluble fiber (beta-glucan), B vitamins, iron, and complex carbohydrates.

brown_rice.advice: Healthy whole grain option. Provides sustained energy and fiber.

nutrition.details: Complex carbs for energy, high in fiber, B vitamins, and magnesium.

quinoa.advice: Complete protein and gluten-free. Excellent grain alternative. Rinse well before cooking.

nutrition.details: A complete protein (all 9 essential amino acids), high in fiber, iron, and magnesium.

whole_wheat_bread.advice: Choose 100% whole grain for maximum nutrition and fiber.

nutrition.details: Good source of fiber, B vitamins, and complex carbohydrates.

white_rice.advice: Safe, but lower in nutrients than brown rice. Good for energy if experiencing nausea.

nutrition.details: Mainly carbohydrates for energy. Often fortified, but lacks fiber.

whole_wheat_pasta.advice: Good source of complex carbs and fiber. Cook thoroughly.

nutrition.details: Provides complex carbs, fiber, and B vitamins.

barley.advice: A very high-fiber grain. Great for digestion.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of fiber, selenium, and B vitamins.
Good source of magnesium, phosphorus, and antioxidants.

whole_grain_cereal.advice: Choose options low in sugar and high in fiber. Check for fortification (iron, folic acid).

nutrition.details: Good source of fiber, B vitamins, and often fortified with iron and folic acid.

almonds.advice: Excellent snack. Rich in healthy fats, protein, and calcium.

nutrition.details: High in healthy fats, protein, fiber, Vitamin E, magnesium, and calcium.

walnuts.advice: The best nut source of plant-based Omega-3s (ALA) for baby's brain.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of Omega-3 (ALA), protein, and antioxidants.

peanuts.advice: Safe unless allergic. Good source of protein and folate.

nutrition.details: Good source of protein, folate, niacin, and healthy fats.

peanut_butter.advice: Choose natural peanut butter without added sugar or hydrogenated oils.

nutrition.details: Good source of protein, healthy fats, and folate.

cashews.advice: Good source of iron and zinc. Eat in moderation.

nutrition.details: Good source of iron, zinc, magnesium, and healthy fats.

chia_seeds.advice: High in fiber and Omega-3s. Helps with constipation. Must be soaked or mixed with liquid.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of fiber, Omega-3 (ALA), protein, and calcium.

flax_seeds.advice: Must be ground to absorb nutrients. High in fiber and Omega-3s.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of fiber and Omega-3 (ALA).

pumpkin_seeds.advice: Great snack, high in iron, magnesium, and zinc.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of iron, magnesium, zinc, and healthy fats.

sunflower_seeds.advice: Rich in Vitamin E and selenium.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of Vitamin E, selenium, and healthy fats.

olive_oil.advice: Excellent healthy fat for cooking and dressings.

nutrition.details: High in monounsaturated fats (heart-healthy) and antioxidants.

coconut_oil.advice: Safe for cooking, but high in saturated fat. Use in moderation.

nutrition.details: High in saturated fat (MCTs). Use sparingly.

butter.advice: Must be from pasteurized milk. Use in moderation due to high saturated fat.

nutrition.details: Saturated fat. Provides some Vitamin A.

water.advice: Stay well hydrated! Essential for all bodily functions, blood volume, and amniotic fluid.

nutrition.details: Crucial for hydration, nutrient transport, waste removal, and amniotic fluid.

coconut_water.advice: Hydrating and rich in electrolytes (potassium). Good for morning sickness. Choose 100% pure.

nutrition.details: High in potassium, provides hydration and electrolytes. Low in sugar compared to juice.

pasteurized_fruit_juice.advice: Must be pasteurized. High in natural sugars, so limit intake. Whole fruit is better.

nutrition.details: Provides vitamins (like Vitamin C), but high in sugar and lacks fiber.

pasteurized_fruit_juice.consumption: Limit to 1 small glass (4-6 oz) daily

decaf_coffee.advice: A good alternative to regular coffee. Still contains a very small amount of caffeine.

nutrition.details: Minimal nutritional value, provides flavor.

coffee.advice: Limit caffeine to < 200mg per day (all sources combined).

nutrition.details: Caffeine is a stimulant. High intake is linked to risks. Provides antioxidants.

black_tea.advice: Contains caffeine. Limit intake to stay under the 200mg daily caffeine limit.

nutrition.details: Contains caffeine and antioxidants.

green_tea.advice: Contains caffeine and may inhibit folic acid absorption. Drink in moderation, not with meals.

nutrition.details: Contains caffeine and high levels of antioxidants (catechins).

green_tea.consumption: Limit to 1-2 cups daily, between meals

idli.advice: Steamed and easily digestible. Healthy breakfast option. Eat with fresh sambar.

nutrition.details: Good source of carbohydrates and protein (from rice/lentils), easily digestible.

dosa.advice: Safe when cooked thoroughly. Fermented for better digestion. Eat with fresh sambar/chutney.

nutrition.details: Carbohydrates, protein from lentils. Can be oily depending on preparation.

sambar.advice: Nutritious lentil and vegetable stew. Ensure served hot and fresh.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of protein, fiber, and various vitamins from lentils and vegetables.

dal_tadka.advice: A safe and highly nutritious lentil dish. Excellent source of protein and iron.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of plant-based protein, iron, folate, and fiber.

dhal_curry.advice: Sri Lankan lentil curry. A staple, safe, and nutritious. Ensure coconut milk is fresh.

nutrition.details: Excellent source of protein, iron, and fiber.

chana_masala.advice: A healthy chickpea dish. Excellent source of protein and fiber.

nutrition.details: High in protein, fiber, folate, and iron.

rajma.advice: Kidney bean curry. A great source of iron and protein. Ensure beans are fully cooked.

nutrition.details: High in protein, fiber, iron, and folate.

palak_paneer.advice: Safe if the paneer is pasteurized and the spinach is well-washed and cooked.

nutrition.details: Rich in iron, folate, and calcium from spinach and paneer. Can be high in fat.

chicken_curry.advice: Ensure the chicken is thoroughly cooked with no pink parts. A good protein source.

nutrition.details: Good source of protein and B vitamins from chicken.

fish_curry.advice: Use low-mercury fish (like tilapia, cod, or local safe varieties) and cook thoroughly.

nutrition.details: Good source of protein and Omega-3s (if using oily fish).

kottu_roti.advice: Ensure all meats (chicken/egg) are thoroughly cooked and the dish is prepared fresh and served piping hot.

nutrition.details: Provides carbohydrates, protein, and vegetables. Can be high in oil and sodium.

string_hoppers.advice: Also known as Idiyappam. Steamed rice noodles. A safe and light option.

nutrition.details: Easily digestible carbohydrates. Low in fat.

hoppers.advice: Also known as Appam. The pancake itself is safe. Ensure any egg in the center is fully cooked (firm yolk).

nutrition.details: Carbohydrates from rice flour. If egg is added, provides protein.

pol_sambol.advice: Coconut relish. Must be freshly prepared to avoid bacterial growth. Eat in moderation.

nutrition.details: Provides healthy fats from coconut, but can be high in calories and very spicy.

gotu_kola_sambol.advice: A herb-based salad. The leaves MUST be washed meticulously to avoid contamination.

nutrition.details: Rich in vitamins and considered a medicinal herb. Healthy if cleaned properly.

gotu_kola_sambol.consumption: 1 serving per week (if confident in washing)

biriyani.advice: Ensure meat (chicken/mutton) is thoroughly cooked and the dish is served hot. High in calories.

nutrition.details: Carbohydrates, protein, but can be very high in fat, sodium, and calories.

dark_chocolate.advice: Safe in moderation. Good source of antioxidants. Contains caffeine.

nutrition.details: High in antioxidants, iron, and magnesium. Contains caffeine and sugar.

ice_cream.advice: Safe if made with pasteurized milk and eggs. Avoid soft-serve (listeria risk). High in sugar.

nutrition.details: High in sugar and fat. Provides some calcium.

hummus.advice: Good source of protein and fiber. Ensure it's store-bought (pasteurized) or freshly made.

nutrition.details: Provides plant-based protein, fiber, and healthy fats (from tahini).

whole_grain_crackers.advice: Good vehicle for cheese or hummus. Check for low sodium.

nutrition.details: Provides fiber and complex carbs.

popcorn.advice: Air-popped popcorn is a healthy, high-fiber snack. Avoid excessive butter and salt.

nutrition.details: A whole grain, high in fiber and antioxidants.

cake_cookies.advice: Safe in moderation. High in sugar, fat, and calories with low nutritional value.

nutrition.details: High in sugar, refined flour, and fats. Provides 'empty' calories.

alcohol.advice: Avoid completely. There is no known safe amount of alcohol during pregnancy.

nutrition.details: Can cause Fetal Alcohol Spectrum Disorders (FASD) and other serious complications.

high_mercury_fish.advice: Avoid shark, swordfish, king mackerel, tilefish, and orange roughy.

nutrition.details: High levels of mercury can damage the fetal nervous system.

canned_albacore_tuna.advice: This is 'white' tuna. It has more mercury than 'light' tuna. Limit severely.

nutrition.details: Moderate mercury levels. 'Light' tuna is a safer choice.

canned_albacore_tuna.consumption: Limit to one 4-6 oz serving per week

raw_sushi.advice: Avoid all sushi made with raw fish due to parasite and bacteria (Vibrio, Salmonella) risk.

nutrition.details: Risk of foodborne illness outweighs any nutritional benefits.

raw_shellfish.advice: Avoid raw oysters, clams, and mussels. High risk of Vibrio and Norovirus.

nutrition.details: High risk of severe food poisoning.

smoked_salmon.advice: Avoid refrigerated smoked salmon (lox, gravlax) due to Listeria risk, unless it's cooked in a dish (e.g., casserole).

nutrition.details: Listeria risk. Canned, shelf-stable smoked salmon is generally safe.

smoked_salmon.consumption: Avoid unless cooked until steaming hot

unpasteurized_dairy.advice: Avoid raw milk and any cheese, yogurt, or juice that is 'unpasteurized'. High risk of Listeria and E. coli.

nutrition.details: Risk of Listeria, Salmonella, E. coli.

soft_cheese.advice: Avoid soft, mold-ripened (Brie, Camembert) and blue-veined (Blue cheese, Gorgonzola) cheeses unless they are explicitly made with PASTEURIZED milk.

nutrition.details: High risk of Listeria if unpasteurized. Read the label carefully.

soft_cheese.consumption: Avoid unless confirmed pasteurized or cooked hot

deli_meats.advice: Avoid cold cuts, ham, turkey, roast beef, etc., from the deli counter due to Listeria risk.

nutrition.details: Listeria can grow on these meats even when refrigerated.

deli_meats.consumption: Avoid unless reheated until steaming hot (165°F)

hot_dogs_processed_meats.advice: Includes hot dogs, sausages, salami, pepperoni. High in sodium and nitrates. Listeria risk.

nutrition.details: Listeria risk and high in preservatives (nitrates/nitrites) and sodium.

hot_dogs_processed_meats.consumption: Avoid, or eat only if cooked until steaming hot

pate_meat_spreads.advice: Avoid refrigerated pâtés or meat spreads due to Listeria risk.

nutrition.details: Listeria risk. Canned, shelf-stable pâté is generally safe.

raw_eggs.advice: Avoid raw or runny eggs. Found in homemade Caesar dressing, mayo, cookie dough, and some sauces (Hollandaise).

nutrition.details: High risk of Salmonella poisoning.

unripe_papaya.advice: Avoid green, unripe papaya. It contains latex that may trigger uterine contractions.

nutrition.details: Contains papain and latex. Ripe papaya is safe in moderation.

raw_sprouts.advice: Avoid all raw sprouts (alfalfa, clover, mung bean, radish). Bacteria (E. coli, Salmonella) are hard to wash off.

nutrition.details: High risk of bacterial contamination.

unwashed_produce.advice: All fruits and vegetables must be washed thoroughly to remove soil and bacteria (Toxoplasmosis, E. coli).

nutrition.details: Risk of Toxoplasmosis from soil.

liver.advice: Limit or avoid. Liver is extremely high in Vitamin A, which can cause birth defects in high doses.

nutrition.details: Dangerously high levels of preformed Vitamin A.

liver.consumption: Avoid or limit to one very small portion per month

excessive_caffeine.advice: Limit total caffeine from all sources (coffee, tea, soda, chocolate) to 200mg per day.

nutrition.details: High intake linked to low birth weight and other risks.

energy_drinks.advice: Avoid. They contain very high levels of caffeine and other stimulants not tested for pregnancy.

nutrition.details: High caffeine, sugar, and other unsafe stimulants.

herbal_tea.advice: Consult your doctor. Some are safe (ginger, peppermint), but many are not (e.g., licorice, ginseng, hibiscus) and can stimulate the uterus.

nutrition.details: Many herbs are not studied for pregnancy safety.

herbal_tea.consumption: Avoid unless specifically approved by your doctor

soft_serve_ice_cream.advice: Avoid. The machines are difficult to clean and can be a breeding ground for Listeria.

nutrition.details: Listeria risk from equipment.

street_food.advice: Avoid due to high risk of contamination from unhygienic water, prep, and storage.

nutrition.details: High risk of foodborne illness (E. coli, Cholera, Hepatitis A).

food_safety_first: Wash hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after handling food.
Wash all fruits and vegetables under running water, even if you plan to peel them.
Use separate cutting boards for raw meat and produce to avoid cross-contamination.
Cook meats, poultry, fish, and eggs to their proper internal temperatures. Use a food thermometer.
Keep hot foods hot (above 140°F) and cold foods cold (below 40°F).
Reheat all leftovers until steaming hot (165°F).
Do not eat food left out at room temperature for more than 2 hours (or 1 hour if it's hot).

key_nutrients_to_focus_on.folate_folic_acid: Found in leafy greens, lentils, beans, fortified cereals. Prevents neural tube defects.
key_nutrients_to_focus_on.iron: Found in lean red meat, poultry, fish, lentils, spinach. Prevents anemia, supports blood volume.
key_nutrients_to_focus_on.calcium: Found in dairy, fortified plant milks, tofu, kale. Builds baby's bones and teeth.
key_nutrients_to_focus_on.protein: Found in meat, poultry, fish, eggs, dairy, legumes, nuts. Essential for tissue growth.
key_nutrients_to_focus_on.omega_3_dha: Found in low-mercury fish (salmon, sardines). Crucial for baby's brain and eye development.
key_nutrients_to_focus_on.vitamin_d: Found in fatty fish, fortified milk, eggs, sunlight. Helps build bones and immunity.
key_nutrients_to_focus_on.choline: Found in eggs, lean meat, fish, peanuts. Critical for brain and spinal cord development.
key_nutrients_to_focus_on.iodine: Found in iodized salt, dairy, seafood. Essential for thyroid function and brain development.

healthy_eating_tips: Eat a variety of colorful foods to get a wide range of nutrients.
Choose whole foods (fruits, vegetables, whole grains) over processed foods.
Eat small, frequent meals to combat nausea and maintain energy levels.
Stay hydrated! Drink 8-12 glasses of water per day.
Take your prenatal vitamin as prescribed by your doctor.
Listen to your hunger and fullness cues.
Limit added sugars, excessive salt, and unhealthy fats.
